title: EXECUTIVE SUMMARY.

B&L international is part of a group of companies with more than 50 years of experience in Real state development, food and beverage trading, logistics and aeronautical industry, also, is partner of major cruise ships companies to supply goods, several port developments, major hotel and entertainment developers and many more, that have provided the perfect scenario to establish a modern, sustainable and competitive network  to support development and operations in a competitive way that benefits all the users of this network.

PRODUCTION:

title: LOGISTICS:

This integration ensures products arrive on time, with top quality, and at an affordable cost to maintain competitiveness. By collaborating with leading distribution chains and logistics operators plus in-house capabilities, we can offer flexible delivery options and ensure reliable support tailored to each user's needs. For example, users will benefit from expedited shipping, real-time tracking, and customized logistics solutions that adapt to changing requirements and will be performed by Majestic Air Cargo, a low cost, perishable specialized and zero intermediation cargo airline.

title: MARKET, INDUSTRY AND OPPRTUNITY ANALYSIS
content:
Industry Landscape.
Global commerce is undergoing a period of profound disruption. Supply chains, once optimized for cost and scale, are now strained by rising tariffs, fragmented trade agreements, and escalating demands for transparency, traceability, and resilience. According to the Bureau of Economic Analysis, U.S. manufacturing output fell to 11.6% of GDP in 2022, down from 16% in 1990, reflecting a long-term erosion of domestic production capacity (Bureau of Economic Analysis, “Value Added by Industry,” 2022). This decline has exposed vulnerabilities in critical sectors such as food systems, logistics infrastructure, and industrial input, especially as geopolitical tensions and climate-related disruptions continue to reshape global sourcing strategies.
At the same time, businesses face mounting pressure to localize operations, reduce carbon footprints, and build adaptive supply networks that can withstand volatility. The traditional model of centralized production and long-haul distribution is no longer sufficient. Instead, the future demands modular, tech-enabled ecosystems that can respond dynamically to shifting market conditions, regulatory landscapes, and consumer expectations.
McKinsey’s latest global survey reveals that 22% of senior executives now rank supply chain disruption as their top business concern, the highest level since the pandemic-era peak in 2022. This shift reflects growing anxiety over geopolitical instability, climate-related events, and the fragility of overextended global sourcing models (McKinsey & Company. Economic Conditions Outlook, September 2025: Trade Policy and Supply Chain Risks Rise to the Fore. Retrieved from https://www.mckinsey.com/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/economic-conditions-outlook).
Key findings include:
Resilience over cost: Companies are increasingly prioritizing supply chain resilience, even at the expense of short-term cost savings.
Regionalization trend: Over 40% of surveyed firms are actively restructuring their supply chains to favor nearshoring and regional hubs, especially in Latin America and Southeast Asia.
Technology adoption: More than 60% of respondents are investing in predictive analytics, digital twins, and AI-powered logistics to improve visibility and responsiveness.
Talent gaps: Labor shortages in logistics and manufacturing are compounding delays and increasing operational risk, prompting firms to invest in workforce development and automation.
The erosion of U.S. manufacturing capacity is no longer just a domestic issue; it’s a strategic vulnerability. As global commerce shifts toward resilience and adaptability, the United States finds itself constrained by aging infrastructure, high labor costs, and a fragmented industrial base. According to the National Association of Manufacturers, over 78% of U.S. manufacturers report difficulty finding skilled labor, while the average cost of domestic production has risen 12.4% since 2020, driven by energy volatility, compliance burdens, and supply chain fragmentation (National Association of Manufacturers. Manufacturers’ Outlook: Trade Uncertainties and Rising Costs Raise the Stakes for a Comprehensive Manufacturing Strategy. March 2025. Retrieved from NAM’s official press release.).
This decline has created dependencies that ripple across sectors. The U.S. now imports over 70% of its critical agricultural inputs, including fertilizers, packaging materials, and perishables processing equipment (U.S. Department of Agriculture, Economic Research Service & Foreign Agricultural Service. Outlook for U.S. Agricultural Trade: August 2025 (AES-133). Retrieved from USDA’s official report). Industrial components, once fabricated domestically, are increasingly sourced from distant markets, many of which are subject to tariff escalation or geopolitical instability. The result is a fragile system: one that struggles to respond to shocks, scale with demand, or support national economic goals.

title: Logistics Industry in 2025.
content:
The global logistics industry in 2025 is navigating one of its most volatile and transformative periods in decades. Once optimized for cost and scale, supply chains are now being reengineered for resilience, responsiveness, and regional control. The convergence of geopolitical instability, climate disruptions, labor shortages, and fragmented infrastructure has exposed deep vulnerabilities in traditional logistics models.
According to Yourco’s 2025 Logistics Challenge Report ( Cain, Robert. Top 11 Challenges in the Logistics Industry and How to Solve Them in 2025. Yourco, May 26, 2025. Retrieved from Yourco’s official blog), over 43% of companies still lack real-time tracking capabilities across multimodal systems, especially when transitioning between sea, air, and ground transport. This lack of visibility leads to cascading delays, inventory losses, and eroded customer trust. Urban congestion, rising fuel prices, and disconnected tech platforms further compound the problem, making logistics execution increasingly unpredictable.

title: Key Challenges Facing the Logistics Sector:
content:
Fragmentation Across Modes: Most logistics networks remain siloed, air, sea, and ground systems operate independently, with limited data exchange or route optimization. This fragmentation leads to inefficiencies, missed handoffs, and inflated costs. Integrated systems are rare, and where they exist, they’re often proprietary and closed loop.
External Disruptions: From extreme weather to political unrest, supply chains are frequently disrupted. The chip shortage of 2022 and port congestion in 2023 revealed how single-point dependencies can freeze entire industries. In 2025, companies are investing in predictive risk models that map vulnerabilities and suggest alternate routings before disruptions escalate.
Labor Shortages: The U.S. logistics sector faces a persistent talent gap. According to the American Trucking Associations, the industry is short over 80,000 drivers (American Trucking Associations. Truck Driver Shortage Statistics: Trends to Know for 2025. FinditParts, January 23, 2025. Retrieved from FinditParts blog), while warehouse labor turnover exceeds 35% annually. This instability drives up costs and reduces throughput.
Sustainability Pressures: ESG mandates and carbon tracking regulations are forcing companies to rethink their transport strategies. Hybrid fleets, LNG-powered vessels, and electric delivery vehicles are gaining traction, but adoption remains uneven.

title: Technology Integration Gaps
content:
While AI, IoT, and robotics are transforming logistics, many firms struggle to integrate these tools across legacy systems. Only 60% of surveyed companies have adopted predictive analytics or digital twins for route planning and inventory control (Yates, Mikayla. Digital Twin Logistics Market 2025: Surging 18% CAGR Driven by AI Integration & Real-Time Supply Chain Optimization. Macho Levante, June 9, 2025. Retrieved from Macho Levante’s industry report).
Integrated Systems: Status and Strategic Potential
Fully integrated ground-sea-air logistics systems remain rare in 2025. Most global players operate segmented networks with limited interoperability. However, Amazon Logistics stands out as a benchmark for vertical integration:
Amazon’s Model: Amazon controls its own air cargo fleet (Amazon Air), operates thousands of last-mile delivery vans, and manages fulfillment centers with robotic automation. It uses proprietary AI to optimize routes, predict demand, and reroute packages in real time.
Success Metrics: Amazon delivers over 72% of its U.S. packages in-house, up from 46% in 2020, and maintains an average delivery time of 1.9 days for Prime orders (Capital One Shopping Research. Amazon Logistics Statistics (2025): Number of Package Deliveries. July 23, 2025. Retrieved from Capital One Shopping’s research portal). Its logistics cost exceeds $100 billion annually, but its control over the supply chain has become a strategic advantage (Logistics Viewpoints. 2025 Update: Amazon’s Supply Chain Keeps Rewriting the Playbook. September 10, 2025.).
Other players like DHL, Maersk, and FedEx are investing in multimodal integration, but few match Amazon’s end-to-end control. Most rely on partnerships and third-party platforms, which introduce latency and reduce flexibility.

title: Technology Trends in Production & Logistics.
content:
In 2025, the convergence of advanced technologies, AI, IoT, robotics, and digital twins, is redefining how production and logistics systems operate. These innovations promise greater efficiency, adaptability, and resilience, but their implementation across industries remains uneven and fragmented.
Adoption Trends Across Production and Logistics.
AI & Machine Learning: AI is increasingly used for demand forecasting, route optimization, and predictive maintenance. In manufacturing, ML models help fine-tune production schedules and reduce waste. In logistics, AI powers dynamic routing and real-time inventory tracking (Future Today Strategy Group. 2025 Tech Trends Report: Supply Chain, Logistics & Manufacturing – 18th Edition. March 2025.)( Bertling Logistics. Trends in Transportation and Logistics 2025. July 22, 2025.).
Digital Twins: These virtual replicas of physical systems are gaining traction in both sectors. In logistics, they simulate warehouse operations and transport flows; in manufacturing, they model production lines to test changes before physical deployment.
IoT & Sensor Networks: IoT devices are embedded across supply chains, from smart pallets to temperature-controlled containers, enabling granular visibility. In production, sensors monitor equipment health and environmental conditions to prevent downtime.
Automation & Robotics: Collaborative robots (cobots) are now common in smart factories, handling repetitive tasks and enhancing precision. Logistics firms deploy autonomous vehicles and robotic picking systems to accelerate fulfillment.
Cloud Infrastructure & Edge Computing: Cloud platforms support centralized data analysis, while edge computing enables real-time decision-making at the source, critical for time-sensitive logistics and decentralized production environments.

title: Implementation Challenges
content:
Despite the promise, integration remains a major hurdle:
Legacy Systems: Many manufacturers and logistics providers still rely on outdated ERP (Enterprise Resource Planning) and WMS (Warehouse Management System) platforms that lack interoperability with modern tools.
Fragmented Initiatives: Technology adoption is often siloed AI for routing, IoT for tracking, robotics for fulfillment without a unified architecture. This leads to inefficiencies and data blind spots.
Cybersecurity Risks: Increased digitization exposes systems to cyber threats. Logistics firms face vulnerabilities in fleet tracking and warehouse automation, while manufacturers risk IP theft and operational sabotage.
Talent Shortages: Skilled labor capable of managing AI systems, robotics, and data analytics is in short supply. Companies struggle to recruit and retain tech-savvy operators and integrators.
Cost Barriers: High upfront investment in automation, sensors, and cloud infrastructure deters smaller firms, especially in emerging markets. ROI timelines remain uncertain for many mid-tier operators.

title: Tech Leaders and Industry Alignment
content:
Major tech firms are driving innovation, but often in isolation from broader industry ecosystems: (Across Logistics. Logistics Trends 2025: Technologies, AI, Challenges and Opportunities. June 9, 2025.)
Amazon: Leads logistics automation with proprietary AI, robotics, and predictive systems. However, its model is vertically integrated and not easily replicable by others.
Siemens & Bosch: Pioneers in industrial automation and digital twin technology, especially in smart manufacturing. Their platforms are widely adopted but often require deep customization.
Microsoft & Google Cloud: Provide scalable cloud and AI infrastructure for logistics and production analytics. Yet, integration with legacy systems remains a challenge for many clients.
Startups & Niche Platforms: Innovators in last-mile delivery, warehouse robotics, and ESG tracking are emerging rapidly, but their solutions often solve isolated problems without systemic integration.
In sum, while technology is reshaping production and logistics, the journey toward unified, adaptive systems is still underway. The landscape is marked by innovation, but also fragmentation, risk, and uneven access. Bridging these gaps will require not just tools, but strategic coordination across industries and regions.

title: MAJESTIC Standard Risk Management Process
content:
A Unified Framework for Resilience, Control, and Strategic Response
In the MAJESTIC P.L.T. ecosystem, risk is not treated as a reactive burden, it is modeled, quantified, and strategically neutralized. Every project, corridor, and operational module within the platform adheres to a standardized risk management process that ensures continuity, investor confidence, and long-term sustainability.
This methodology is designed to be modular, scalable, and data-driven aligning with MAJESTIC’s core principles of operational clarity, founder empowerment, and hemispheric control.

title: Methodology Overview: Quantifying Risk, Structuring Response
content:
Each risk is evaluated across two primary dimensions:
Influence Assessment
O.P. (Operational Probability): Likelihood of the risk occurring within the operational context.
P.I. (Project Impact): Degree to which the risk affects market access, buyer behavior, or trade flow.
Each dimension is rated on a 5-point scale:
VL (Very Low) = 1
L (Low) = 2
M (Medium) = 3
H (High) = 4
VH (Very High) = 5
A specific average (ESP) is calculated for each risk, and a general average (GRAL) is derived from the category (e.g., market, logistics, digital security).
Management Mechanism Evaluation
Each risk is matched with a mitigation strategy, evaluated across:
Capability: The platform’s ability to implement the strategy
Rated VL to VH (1 to 5)
Cost: Investment required to deploy the mechanism
Inverted scale: VL = 5 (high cost), VH = 1 (low cost)
The management ESP is the average of capability and cost. This is then compared to the risk ESP:
If management ESP > risk ESP, the risk is considered controlled.
If management ESP < risk ESP, additional strategies must be deployed.
A final control index is calculated:
Management GRAL – Risk GRAL = Net Control Value
Positive = Controlled environment
Negative = High-risk exposure requiring intervention
Application Across MAJESTIC Projects
This methodology is embedded into every MAJESTIC initiative, from FRESH-24’s corridor operations to future platform modules. It ensures that each project:
Identifies risks early, using structured diagnostics and stakeholder input.
Quantifies exposure, enabling investor-grade transparency and prioritization.
Aligns mitigation strategies with operational capacity and financial logic.
Monitors performance, using real-time dashboards and KPI-linked alerts.
Adapts dynamically, refining strategies as corridor conditions evolve.
Each operational unit maintains its own risk matrix, but shares common services for legal advisory, ESG compliance, and simulation modeling, ensuring both autonomy and strategic cohesion.
Example Categories Applied
Market Risks: Seasonal demand volatility, niche dependency, buyer concentration.
Logistics Risks: Route disruption, cold-chain failure, customs bottlenecks.
Regulatory Risks: Trade agreement shifts, ESG compliance tightening.
Digital Risks: Cyberattacks, data breaches, platform adoption resistance.
Team Risks: Talent availability, regional fluency, operational discipline.
Each risk is mapped, valued, and tracked using the MAJESTIC matrix, ensuring that no corridor or module operates blindly. This process transforms uncertainty into structured response.
Strategic Impact
The MAJESTIC Risk Management Process is more than a safeguard, it’s a strategic asset. It enables:
Investor confidence through quantifiable control.
Operational resilience across volatile regions.
Scalable governance that adapts to corridor complexity.
Founder empowerment, allowing proactive decision-making at every level.
